name: Hausa
notes: Has used Latin-based alphabet since 1930, left-to-right.  Used an Arabic alphabet previously

name: Hebrew
notes: Modern Hebrew. Code changed in 1989 from original ISO 639:1988, iw.[1]

name: Central Khmer
native_name: ខ្មែរ, ខេមរភាសា, ភាសាខ្មែរ
iso_endonym: ខ្មែរ, ខេមរភាសា, ភាសាខ្មែរ
notes: also known as Khmer or Cambodian

name: Indonesian
notes: Covered by macrolanguage [ms/msa]. Changed in 1989 from original ISO 639:1988, in[1].

name: Malay
notes: macrolanguage, Standard Malay is [zsm], Indonesian is [id/ind]

name: Tahitian
notes: One of the Reo Mā`ohi (languages of French Polynesia)

name: Interlingua (International Auxiliary Language Association)
notes: constructed by International Auxiliary Language Association

name: Interlingue, Occidental
notes: constructed by Edgar de Wahl, first published in 1922

name: Ido
notes: constructed by De Beaufront, 1907, as variation of Esperanto

name: Bislama
notes: Language formed from English and Ni-Vanuatu, with some French influence.

name: Armenian
notes: also known as Հայերէն; ISO 639-3 code "hye" is for Eastern Armenian, "hyw" is for Western Armenian, and "xcl" is for Classical Armenian

name: Bihari languages
notes: collective language code for Bhojpuri, Magahi, and Maithili

name: Church Slavic, Old Slavonic, Church Slavonic, Old Bulgarian, Old Church Slavonic
iso_name: Church Slavic, Old Slavonic, Church Slavonic, Old Bulgarian, Old Church Slavonic
notes: ancient, in use by Orthodox Church

name: Romanian
notes: The identifiers mo and mol are deprecated, leaving ro and ron (639-2/T) and rum (639-2/B) the current language identifiers to be used for the variant of the Romanian language also known as Moldavian and Moldovan in English and moldave in French. The identifiers mo and mol will not be assigned to different items, and recordings using these identifiers will not be invalid.

name: Sanskrit
notes: ancient, still spoken, also known as Saṃskṛta

name: Serbian
notes: The ISO 639-2/T code srp deprecated the ISO 639-2/B code scc[2]

name: Yiddish
notes: macrolanguage. Changed in 1989 from original ISO 639:1988, ji.[1]

name: Chinese
native_name: 中文 (Zhōngwén), 汉语, 漢語
iso_endonym: 中文 (Zhōngwén), 汉语, 漢語

name: Official Aramaic (700-300 BCE); Imperial Aramaic (700-300 BCE)
iso_name: Official Aramaic (700-300 BCE); Imperial Aramaic (700-300 BCE)

name: Low German
iso_name: Low German; Low Saxon; German, Low; Saxon, Low

name: Classical Newari; Old Newari; Classical Nepal Bhasa
iso_name: Classical Newari; Old Newari; Classical Nepal Bhasa

name: Zaza; Dimili; Dimli; Kirdki; Kirmanjki; Zazaki
iso_name: Zaza; Dimili; Dimli; Kirdki; Kirmanjki; Zazaki
